question: Microscopic examination of articular surface of a synovial joint demonstrates?
exp: ANSWER: (A) Hyaline cartilageREF: Basic histology, Carlos & Jose, 11th edition, Chapter 7, Cartilage, Textbook of human histology 4th e p. 92-94See APPENDIX-2 below for "Types of cartilage" APPENDIX - 2Types of Cartilages Hyaline CartilageElastic CartilageFibrocatilageCompositionType II collagenChondroitin sulfateType II collagenElastin fibersType I collagenPerichondriumPresentPresentAbsent Articular cartilageArytenoid cartilageThyroid cartilageCricoid cartilageEpiphyseal growth plateNasal septumCostal cartilage of ribsAuricleAuditory tubeEpiglottisCuneiform cartilage of larynxEpiglottisExternal auditory canalArticular discsIntervertebral discsMenisciPubic symphysisGlenoid labrumAcetabular labrum

question: White fibrocartilage is present in all EXCEPT:
exp: ANSWER: (D) PinnaREF: Basic histology, Carlos & Jose, 11th edition, Chapter 7, Cartilage, Textbook of human histology 4th e p. 92-94See APPENDIX-2 below for ''Types of cartilage""Pinna or auricle is formed of elastic cartilage not fibrocartilage" APPENDIX - 2Types of Cartilages Hyaline CartilageElastic CartilageFibrocatilageCompositionType II collagenChondroitin sulfateType II collagenElastin fibersType I collagenPerichondriumPresentPresentAbsent Articular cartilageArytenoid cartilageThyroid cartilageCricoid cartilageEpiphyseal growth plateNasal septumCostal cartilage of ribsAuricleAuditory tubeEpiglottisCuneiform cartilage of larynxEpiglottisExternal auditory canalArticular discsIntervertebral discsMenisciPubic symphysisGlenoid labrumAcetabular labrum

question: Which of the following bones has no medullary cavity -
exp: Ans 'b' i.e., Clavicle CLASSIFICATION OF BONESA ACCORDING TO SH APEI. Long bones : Each long bone has a shaft (diaphysis) and 2 expanded ends (epiphysis) wich are smooth and articular. The shaft has a nutrient foramen directed away from the growing end.Typical long bones : Humerus, femurMiniature long bones : Metacarpals, phalangesModified long bones : Have no medullary cavity. Eg. Clavicle and body of vertebraII Short bones : Carpals and tarsalsIII Flat bones : cranial bones, ribs, sternum, scapulaIV Irregular bones : Vertebrae, hip bone, bones in the base of the skullV. Pneumatic bones : maxilla, sphenoid, ethmoidVI Sesamoid bones : Found embedded in tendons and capsules. They have no periosteum and ossify- after birth. Eg. Patella, pisiform, fabellaB. DEVELOPMENTAL CLASSIFICATIONI Membrane bones (Intramembranous or mesenchymal ossification)o Bones of the skull vault and facial boneso A defect in membranous ossification causes a syndrome called cleidocranial dysostosis, characterized by :Varying degrees of aplasia of claviclesIncrease in transverse diameter of craniumRetardation in fontanelle ossificationII Cartilaginous bones (Enchondral ossification)o They are derived from preformes cartilaginous models,o Bones of limbs, vertebral column, thoracic cage,o A defect in enchondral ossification causes achondroplasia.III. Membrano - cartilaginous boneso They ossify- partly in membrane and partly in cartilage,o Clavicle, mandible, sphenoidC. STRUCTURAL CLASSIFICATIONI. Compact boneo Dense but extremely porouso Best developed in the cortex of the long boneso It is an adaption to bending and twisting forcesII Cancellous/trabecular boneo Made up of a meshwork of trabeculaeo It is an adaption to compressive forcesD. MICROSCOPIC CLASSIFICATIONI Lamellar bone : most of the human bonesII Fibrous bones : young fetal bonesIII DentineIV Cement : occurs in teeth

question: Which of the following is example of hyaline cartilage?
exp: ANSWER: (B) ThyroidREF: Basic histology, Carlos & Jose, 11th edition, Chapter 7, Cartilage, Textbook of human histology 4th e p. 92-94See APPENDIX-2 below for ''Types of cartilage" APPENDIX - 2Types of Cartilages Hyaline CartilageElastic CartilageFibrocatilageCompositionType II collagenChondroitin sulfateType II collagenElastin fibersType I collagenPerichondriumPresentPresentAbsent Articular cartilageArytenoid cartilageThyroid cartilageCricoid cartilageEpiphyseal growth plateNasal septumCostal cartilage of ribsAuricleAuditory tubeEpiglottisCuneiform cartilage of larynxEpiglottisExternal auditory canalArticular discsIntervertebral discsMenisciPubic symphysisGlenoid labrumAcetabular labrumExample

question: Elastic cartilage is seen in -
exp: Ans. is 'c' i.e., Epiglottis {Ref: Textbook of general anatomy/p. 112)o TMJ is a synovial joint of Condylar variety.o The articular surfaces are covered with fibrocartilage. The joint cavity' is divided into upper and lower parts by an intra-articular disc.CARTILAGE SITESo Hyaline cartilage--Articular cartilage in synovial jointsCricoid, thyroid, trachea, bronchiCostal cartilageNasal cartilageEpiphyseal plateArytenoid cartilageo Fibrocartilage--Labrum - glenoid acetabularSymphysisArticular disco Elastic cartilage--Eustachian tubeExternal auditory meatus - auricleComiculate, cuneiform cartilageEpiglottis
